facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1312 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 1, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1312 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated October 1, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961.

facts.text: Mysore High Court judgment dated October 1, 1962 directed the appellant to determine the salary payable to the respondent assuming he had been permitted to cross the efficiency bar in time scale of pay of Rs. 900-50-1200-EB-75-1500 in Osmania Sikka rupees.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought by special leave from the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 in Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961 directing the appellant to determine the salary payable to the respondent on the basis that he had been permitted to cross the efficiency bar in time scale of pay of Rs. 900-50-1200-EB-75-1500 in Osmania Sikka rupees.

facts.text: The High Court directed that increments above the efficiency bar be withheld by the appellant should not be paid to the respondent and the salary so determined should be taken into account for pension.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also directed by the same judgment that the increments above the efficiency bar be withheld by the appellant should number be paid to him and the salary so determined should be taken into account for determining the amount of pension payable to the respondent in accordance with the relevant rules.

facts.text: The respondent was working as an Executive Engineer in the Public Works Department of the Hyderabad State and was in charge of certain project works during June 1949 to September 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was working as an Executive Engineer in the Public Works Department of the Hyderabad State and was in charge of certain project works during the period June 1949 to September 1950.

facts.text: Explanation of the respondent was called for in respect of certain alleged irregularities in the execution of certain project works.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of some information the explanation of the respondent was called for in respect of certain alleged irregularities in the execution of certain project works.

facts.text: The respondent sent explanations dated June 14, 1951 and December 10, 1951 to the Superintending Engineer, Munirabad.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent sent in his explanations dated June 14, 1951 and December 10, 1951 to the Superintending Engineer, Munirabad.

facts.text: In October 1953 the Enquiry Officer concluded that some loss had been caused in respect of four projects more due to lack of foresight and organising capacity on the part of the respondent than to any intentional misappropriation.

anchor.surface_text: In October 1953 the Enquiry Officer came to the companyclusion that some loss had been caused in respect of four projects more due to lack of foresight and organising capacity on the part of the respondent than to any intentional misappropriation

facts.text: Show cause notice issued on March 11, 1955 asking respondent why he should not be stopped from crossing efficiency bar from February 9, 1952 and why Rs. 23,371/- should not be recovered from his salary for loss caused by negligence.

anchor.surface_text: and a show cause numberice was issued on March 11, 1955 asking the respondent to show cause why he should number be stopped from crossing the efficiency bar with effect from February 9, 1952 and why a sum of Rs. 23,371/.- should number be recovered from his salary on account of the loss caused to the Government by the respondents negligence.

facts.text: After respondent showed cause, the matter was sent by the Government to the Public Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: After the respondent had shown cause the matter was sent by the Government to the Public Service Commission.

facts.text: Public Service Commission recommended stopping respondent at efficiency bar for 1952 to 1957 and recovery of pecuniary loss.

anchor.surface_text: The Public Service Commission recommended that in addition to stopping the respondent at the efficiency bar for the period 1952 to 1957 as recommended by the Government, the pecuniary loss caused to the Government should be recovered from the respondent.

facts.text: On November 1, 1956 States Reorganisation came into force and services of respondent transferred to State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: On November 1, 1956 the States Reorganisation came into force and the services of the respondent stood transferred to the State of Mysore.

facts.text: Mysore Government order dated October 14, 1958 directed compulsory retirement of respondent and recovery of Rs. 4,576/- loss.

anchor.surface_text: By its order dated October 14, 1958 the Mysore Government directed that the respondent should be retired companypulsorily from service and should also be asked to make good sum of Rs. 4,576/- being the amount of loss caused to Government in the above companynection.

facts.text: Respondent challenged the October 14, 1958 order by writ petition on grounds that Enquiry Officer exonerated him of all charges except one and report not furnished.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged this order by a writ petition on the ground that the Enquiry Officer at Hyderabad had exonerated him of all the charges excepting one and also. because the report of the Enquiry Officer was number furnished to the respondent.

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed the writ petition and quashed the Government order.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore allowed the writ petition and quashed the order of the Government.

facts.text: By order dated December 10, 1960 the respondent who was to retire on October 27, 1960 upon completing age of 55 years was continued in service under suspension pending disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: except to state that by an order made on December 10, 1960 he respondent who was to have retired with effect from October 27, 1960, the date on which he companypleted the age of 55 years was companytinued in service but under suspension pending companypletion of the disciplinary proceedings against him

facts.text: Government order dated May 19, 1961 revoked the December 10, 1960 order and permitted respondent to retire dropping disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Government by a subsequent order dated May 19, 1961 revoked the previous order of December 10, 1960 and permitted the respondent to retire dropping altogether the disciplinary proceedings against him.

facts.text: After retirement respondent filed Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961 for declaration of crossing efficiency bar on February 9, 1952, increments, pay difference and pension on enhanced salary.

anchor.surface_text: After his retirement the respondent flied writ petition No. 1280 of 1961 praying for declaration that he should be regarded as having crossed the efficiency bar in his pay scale on February 9, 1952 and that he should be given all the increments after the efficiency bar in the pay scale of an Executive Engineer and that he should be paid the difference and his pension should be fixed on the basis of enhanced salary claimed by him.

facts.text: Mysore State resisted the claim on ground that under r. 38 of Hyderabad Civil Service Rules specific order required to cross efficiency bar.

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the respondent was resisted by the Mysore State on the ground that under r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules a specific order ought to be made permitting the respondent to cross the efficiency bar.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's contention and held that upon dropping proceedings increment withheld by way of penalty should be restored for pension calculation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention of the appellant and held that companysequent upon the dropping of the proceeding against the respondent the increment withheld by way of penalty should be restored and the increased salary should be taken into account in fixing the amount of pension payable to the respondent.

facts.text: During appeal hearing, respondent's counsel stated that r. 38 was not in operation when respondent due for crossing efficiency bar but a similar rule was.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the case was argued by both the parties on the assumption that r. 38 applied to the case of the respondent. During the hearing of the appeal in this Court it was stated by Mr. Iyengar that when the respondent became due for crossing the efficiency bar r. 38 as it stands at present was number in operation.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Mysore High Court judgment dated October 1, 1962 and ordered dismissal of the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we held that this appeal should be allowed and the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 should be set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent should be ordered to be dismissed.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated October 1, 1962 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961. Niren De, Attorney-General, S.S. Javali and S.P. Nayar, for the appellant. R.L. Iyengar and A. G. Ratnaparkhi, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J.

Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961. Niren De, Attorney-General, S.S. Javali and S.P. Nayar, for the appellant. R.L. Iyengar and A. G. Ratnaparkhi, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami, J. This appeal is brought by special leave from the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 in Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961 directing the appellant to determine the salary payable to the respondent on the basis that he had been permitted to cross the efficiency bar in time scale of pay of Rs. 900-50-1200-EB-75-1500 in Osmania Sikka rupees.

This appeal is brought by special leave from the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 in Writ Petition No. 1280 of 1961 directing the appellant to determine the salary payable to the respondent on the basis that he had been permitted to cross the efficiency bar in time scale of pay of Rs. 900-50-1200-EB-75-1500 in Osmania Sikka rupees. The High Court also directed by the same judgment that the increments above the efficiency bar be withheld by the appellant should not be paid to him and the salary so determined should be taken into account for determining the amount of pension payable to the respondent in accordance with the relevant rules.

The claim of the respondent was resisted by the Mysore State on the ground that under r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules a specific order ought to be made permitting the respondent to cross the efficiency bar. The High Court rejected the contention of the appellant and held that consequent upon the dropping of the proceeding against the respondent the increment withheld by way of penalty should be restored and the increased salary should be taken into account in fixing the amount of pension payable to the respondent.

concepts.interpretation: before the respondent could claim payment of increments next above the bar it is necessary that the Government should make a special order sanctioning such payment

concepts.unlisted_description: Requires specific sanction to cross efficiency bar in time scale

anchor.surface_text: Rule 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Services Rules, 1952 reads as follows Where an efficiency bar is prescribed in a time scale the increment next above the bar shall not be given to a Government servant without the specific sanction of the authority empowered to withhold increments. Rule 52 of the Mysore Civil Services Rules, 1958 is in the same language. as r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules. On behalf of the respondent it was contended that the withholding of the increment of the respondent at the efficiency bar was intended to operate as a penalty for alleged misconduct.

concepts.interpretation: an express order of the appropriate authority is necessary before the respondent is allowed to cross the efficiency bar

anchor.surface_text: Rule 52 of the Mysore Civil Services Rules, 1958 is in the same language as r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules. On behalf of the respondent it was contended that the withholding of the increment of the respondent at the efficiency bar was intended to operate as a penalty for alleged misconduct. It was said that upon the facts of the case the only conclusion possible was that the Government wanted to stop the respondent at the efficiency bar in the time scale with a view to reimburse itself at the expense of the respondent the loss said to have been caused by him to the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged this order by a writ petition on the ground that the Enquiry Officer at Hyderabad had exonerated him of all the charges excepting one and also because the report of the Enquiry Officer was not furnished to the respondent. The High Court of Mysore allowed the writ petition and quashed the order of the Government.

issues.text: Whether under r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules a specific order ought to be made permitting the respondent to cross the efficiency bar

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the respondent was resisted by the Mysore State on the ground that under r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules a specific order ought to be made permitting the respondent to cross the efficiency bar. The High Court rejected the contention of the appellant and held that consequent upon the dropping of the proceeding against the respondent the increment withheld by way of penalty should be restored and the increased salary should be taken into account in fixing the amount of pension payable to the respondent.

issues.text: Whether the withholding of the increment of the respondent at the efficiency bar was intended to operate as a penalty for alleged misconduct

anchor.surface_text: Rule 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Services Rules, 1952 reads as follows Where an efficiency bar is prescribed in a time scale the increment next above the bar shall not be given to a Government servant without the specific sanction of the authority empowered to withhold increments. Rule 52 of the Mysore Civil Services Rules, 1958 is in the same language. as r. 38 of the Hyderabad Civil Service Rules. On behalf of the respondent it was contended that the withholding of the increment of the respondent at the efficiency bar was intended to operate as a penalty for alleged misconduct.

issues.text: Whether after the dropping of disciplinary proceedings without recording any finding of guilt the Government had waived their right to stop the respondent at the efficiency bar for administrative reasons under r. 38

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, argued that after the dropping of disciplinary proceedings against the respondent without recording any finding of guilt no penalty could be imposed. It was Contended that once the Government had taken the decision to stop the respondent at the efficiency bar by way of penalty it must be held that the Government had waived their right to stop the respondent at the efficiency bar for administrative reasons under r. 38.

issues.text: Whether the result claimed by the respondent (crossing the efficiency bar) automatically follows from the dropping of the disciplinary proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no warrant for the contentions advanced on behalf of the respondent. It is manifest that in view of the language of r. 38 of the Hyderabad Rules and r. 52 of the Mysore Rules before the respondent could claim payment of increments next above the bar it is necessary that the Government should make a special order sanctioning such payment. It is true that disciplinary proceedings against the respondent were dropped but the result claimed by the respondent cannot automatically follow a result of the dropping of the disciplinary proceedings.

issues.text: Whether the stoppage at efficiency bar had connection with the recovery of loss sustained by the Government such that it was imposed to reimburse the loss

anchor.surface_text: In this connection the Attorney General pointed out that the notice dated March 16, 1955 against the respondent asked him to show cause why 1 he should not be stopped from crossing the efficiency bar and 2 why a sum of Rs. 23,371-14-2 should not be recovered from him on account of loss caused to the Government by his negligence. The stoppage at efficiency bar had no connection with the recovery of loss sustained by the Government and it cannot, therefore, be said that the Government wanted to impose the efficiency bar because it wanted to reimburse itself for the loss caused by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion there is no warrant for the contentions advanced on behalf of the respondent. It is manifest that in view of the language of r. 38 of the Hyderabad Rules and r. 52 of the Mysore Rules before the respondent could claim payment of increments next above the bar it is necessary that the Government should make a special order sanctioning such payment.

edges.explanation: h2 directly addresses i4 by stating that dropping disciplinary proceedings does not automatically entitle the respondent to cross the efficiency bar

anchor.surface_text: It is true that disciplinary proceedings against the respondent were dropped but the result claimed by the respondent cannot automatically follow as a result of the dropping of the disciplinary proceedings.

For these reasons we held that this appeal should be allowed and the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 should be set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent should be ordered to be dismissed.

edges.explanation: h3 holds stoppage at efficiency bar had no connection to loss recovery and not imposed to reimburse, addressing i5

anchor.surface_text: In this connection the Attorney General pointed out that the notice dated March 16, 1955 against the respondent asked him to show cause why 1 he should not be stopped from crossing the efficiency bar and 2 why a sum of Rs. 23,371-14-2 should not be recovered from him on account of loss caused to the Government by his negligence. The stoppage at efficiency bar had no connection with the recovery of loss sustained by the Government and it cannot, therefore, be said that the Government wanted to impose the efficiency bar because it wanted to reimburse itself for the loss caused by the respondent.

For these reasons we held that this appeal should be allowed and the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 should be set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent should be ordered to be dismissed.

edges.explanation: The holding 'there is no warrant for the contentions advanced on behalf of the respondent' addresses the issue of waiver following dropped proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It was Contended that once the Government had taken the decision to stop the respondent at the efficiency bar by way of penalty it must be held that the Government had waived their right to stop the respondent at the efficiency bar for administrative reasons under r. 38. In our opinion there is no warrant for the contentions advanced on behalf of the respondent.

For these reasons we held that this appeal should be allowed and the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 should be set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent should be ordered to be dismissed.

edges.explanation: h6 addresses i1 by rejecting the idea of deemed sanction under r. 38, affirming need for specific order

anchor.surface_text: It is not, therefore, possible to accept the contention of the respondent that the Government must be deemed to have given specific sanction under r. 38 of the Hyderabad Rules permitting the respondent to cross the efficiency bar merely because disciplinary proceedings against him had been dropped for certain reasons.

For these reasons we held that this appeal should be allowed and the judgment of the Mysore High Court dated October 1, 1962 should be set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent should be ordered to be dismissed.
